item.title: The application of the EU Charter of Rights to derogations in the internal market of Member States.
item.description: By Steve Peers The recent ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) in the Pfleger case confirmed a significant point about the reach of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. However, it also indirectly raised some doubts about the Charter’s effectiveness in such situations. This case revolved around Austria’s limitations on gambling machines. The CJEU has handled numerous cases concerning national gambling restrictions, a topic not comprehensively addressed by EU law but still generally falling under EU internal market rules.

item.title: Demonstrating the Efficacy of Health Interventions in Cases of Free Movement
item.description: Angus MacCulloch, Lancaster University Law School Two recent rulings concerning the free movement of goods (Articles 34/36 TFEU) highlight the critical importance of strong evidence when governments attempt to justify public health interventions in the market. The first example, a judgment from the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) in Case C-148/15 Deutsche Parkinson Vereinigung, addressed the legality of fixed prices for prescription medicines in Germany. The second, a ruling from the Inner House of the Court of Session in Scotland in Scotch Whisky Assoc v LA [2016] CSIH 77, upheld the Scottish Government’s plan to introduce minimum unit pricing (MUP) for alcohol, finding it compatible with Article 34.

item.title: Who should have control over the 'emergency brake' on benefits for EU citizens: the Commission or the Council?
item.description: Steve Peers, Professor of Law, University of Essex During the UK’s negotiations to leave the European Union, a key point of contention arose: the process for enacting an “emergency brake” to restrict EU citizens’ access to in-work benefits. Should a Member State have the authority to implement this measure independently, perhaps with a requirement to inform the Commission and Council? Or should it be required to submit a request, leaving the decision of authorization to the Commission and/or Council?
